elements.content: Uranyl ion complexation by cucurbit[n]urils (CBn, n = 6, 7, 8) was investigated, mostly under hydrothermal conditions, and the crystal structure of six novel complexes was determined. In compounds [UO2(H2O)5](NO3)2·CB6·4H2O (1) and [UO2(NO3)2(H2O)2]·CB6·7H2O (2), CB6 acts as a second-sphere ligand through hydrogen bonding to uranyl aquo ligands, while in all other complexes, [(UO2)4(CB6)O2(OH)2(H2O)6](NO3)2·CB6·8H2O (3), [(UO2)2(CB6)3(H2O)6][(UO2)2(NO3)4(C10H16O4)]2·CB6·8H2O (4), [(UO2)2(CB7)(SO4)2(H2O)2]·4H2O (5), and [(UO2)6(CB8)(SO4)6(H2O)10]·18H2O (6), uranyl coordination to one or two CB carbonyl groups is present. A one-dimensional polymer with tetranuclear, μ3-oxo-bridged subunits and a three-decker dinuclear complex are formed in 3 and 4, respectively, with in both cases numerous CH···O interactions between CB6 molecules, either within the complex or involving other CB6 molecules present as guests. The CB7 and CB8 complexes 5 and 6, both obtained in the presence of sulfuric acid, involve either dimeric (5) or polymeric (6) uranyl sulfate subunits, which are further connected through tetradentate CB molecules to give two-dimensional frameworks. Cylindrical channels result from the stacking of CB7 molecules in complex 5.

The CB7 and CB8 complexes 5 and 6, both obtained in the presence of sulfuric acid, involve either dimeric (5) or polymeric (6) uranyl sulfate subunits, which are further connected through tetradentate CB molecules to give two-dimensional frameworks. Cylindrical channels result from the stacking of CB7 molecules in complex 5.

elements.content: The first examples of uranyl-coordinated cucurbiturils are presented. Besides a dinuclear molecular complex, different polymeric assemblages are described, one-dimensional with tetranuclear, μ3-oxo-bridged subunits, and two-dimensional with uranyl sulfate dimeric or polymeric subunits. One of the frameworks presents a nanotubular arrangement of cylindrical channels.

Besides a dinuclear molecular complex, different polymeric assemblages are described, one-dimensional with tetranuclear, μ3-oxo-bridged subunits, and two-dimensional with uranyl sulfate dimeric or polymeric subunits. One of the frameworks presents a nanotubular arrangement of cylindrical channels.

elements.content: Cucurbiturils are cyclic, bis-methylene-linked glycoluril oligomers displaying a rigid, pumpkin-like shape, which have been much investigated in recent years. Besides cucurbit[6]uril (noted CB6 hereafter), which was first discovered, other members of the cucurbit[n]uril family (Scheme ) were later synthesized (n = 5, 7, 8, 10), thus providing a series of molecular hosts with a cavity of varying size. These molecules were used in many remarkable supramolecular assemblages, such as host−guest inclusion complexes, pseudorotaxanes, polyrotaxanes and necklaces, with potential applications as synthetic receptors, molecular machines, switches or biomimetic species, among others; CB6 was also shown recently to behave as an organic porous material. Although they are rather weak donors, the carbonyl groups lining the portals of CBs can be involved in hydrogen bonds or metal ion coordination, as well as in charge-dipole interactions with included guests. The metal-complexing properties of CBs have been thoroughly investigated, particularly in the cases of alkali, alkaline-earth and lanthanide cations. Some cases of carbonyl-complexed d-block metal ions are known, as well as examples of second-sphere complexation through hydrogen bonds to aquo ligands. Concerning actinide ions, the crystal structures of only two compounds have been reported by Fedin et al.: in [Th2(CB6)Cl2(H2O)10]Cl6, one Th(IV) cation bound to three adjacent carbonyl groups is complexed at each portal of CB6, while in [(UO2)4(μ3-O)2(μ2-Cl)4(H2O)6]·CB6 there is no uranium−carbonyl bond, the tetranuclear uranyl complex being only hydrogen bonded to the macrocycle. Considering the ease with which CBs coordinate to lanthanide ions, it seemed worthwhile to investigate uranyl complexation under varying conditions to check for the possibility of uranyl-carbonyl bonds. The existence of such bonds seemed all the more possible that the carbonyl groups of CBs interact more strongly with cations than crown ether oxygen atoms, which are known to bind to uranyl cations, and also that numerous examples of uranyl bonding to urea derivatives are reported in the Cambridge Structural Database (CSD, Version 5.29).The complexes reported herein, most of them having been obtained under hydrothermal conditions, show that, besides second-sphere complexation, direct uranyl-CBs bonding is possible and gives hybrid metal-organic species with unprecedented architectures.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Cucurbiturils are cyclic, bis-methylene-linked glycoluril oligomers displaying a rigid, pumpkin-like shape, which have been much investigated in recent years. Besides cucurbit[6]uril (noted CB6 hereafter), which was first discovered, other members of the cucurbit[n]uril family (Scheme ) were later synthesized (n = 5, 7, 8, 10), thus providing a series of molecular hosts with a cavity of varying size. These molecules were used in many remarkable supramolecular assemblages, such as host-guest inclusion complexes, pseudorotaxanes, polyrotaxanes and necklaces, with potential applications as synthetic receptors, molecular machines, switches or biomimetic species, among others; CB6 was also shown recently to behave as an organic porous material. Although they are rather weak donors, the carbonyl groups lining the portals of CBs can be involved in hydrogen bonds or metal ion coordination, as well as in charge-dipole interactions with included guests. The metal-complexing properties of CBs have been thoroughly investigated, particularly in the cases of alkali, alkaline-earth and lanthanide cations. Some cases of carbonyl-complexed d-block metal ions are known, as well as examples of second-sphere complexation through hydrogen bonds to aquo ligands. Concerning actinide ions, the crystal structures of only two compounds have been reported by Fedin et al.: in [Th2(CB6)Cl2(H2O)10]Cl6, one Th(IV) cation bound to three adjacent carbonyl groups is complexed at each portal of CB6, while in [(UO2)4(μ3-O)2(μ2-Cl)4(H2O)6]⋅CB6 there is no uranium-carbonyl bond, the tetranuclear uranyl complex being only hydrogen bonded to the macrocycle. Considering the ease with which CBs coordinate to lanthanide ions, it seemed worthwhile to investigate uranyl complexation under varying conditions to check for the possibility of uranyl-carbonyl bonds. The existence of such bonds seemed all the more possible that the carbonyl groups of CBs interact more strongly with cations than crown ether oxygen atoms, which are known to bind to uranyl cations, and also that numerous examples of uranyl bonding to urea derivatives are reported in the Cambridge Structural Database (CSD, Version 5.29).The complexes reported herein, most of them having been obtained under hydrothermal conditions, show that, besides second-sphere complexation, direct uranyl-CBs bonding is possible and gives hybrid metal-organic species with unprecedented architectures.

elements.content:
Caution! Because uranium is a radioactive and chemically toxic element, uranium-containing samples must be handled with suitable care and protection.

UO2(NO3)2·6H2O was purchased from Prolabo, cucurbit[6]uril hydrate from Fluka and cucurbit[7]uril hydrate from Aldrich. The water content in the two latter compounds is ca. 5 and 10 water molecules per cucurbituril molecule, respectively, according to the analyses provided by the seller. Elemental analyses were performed by Analytische Laboratorien GmbH at Lindlar, Germany.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis

 Caution! Because uranium is a radioactive and chemically toxic element, uranium-containing samples must be handled with suitable care and protection. 

UO2(NO3)2⋅6H2O was purchased from Prolabo, cucurbit[6]uril hydrate from Fluka and cucurbit[7]uril hydrate from Aldrich. The water content in the two latter compounds is ca. 5 and 10 water molecules per cucurbituril molecule, respectively, according to the analyses provided by the seller. Elemental analyses were performed by Analytische Laboratorien GmbH at Lindlar, Germany.

elements.content: CB6·5H2O (35 mg, 0.032 mmol) and a 4-fold excess of UO2(NO3)2·6H2O (64 mg, 0.127 mmol) were dissolved in demineralized water (3 mL) and 0.5 mL of HNO3 (65% in water) was added. Upon standing at room temperature, the solution deposited light yellow crystals of complex 1 within one day. The product was recovered after filtration and washed with water (17 mg, 34% yield on the basis of CB6). Anal. Calcd for C36H54N26O29U: C, 27.84; H, 3.51; N, 23.45. Found: C, 27.52; H, 3.60; N, 23.18%. The same complex was also obtained under hydrothermal conditions: CB6·5H2O (35 mg, 0.032 mmol), an 8-fold excess of UO2(NO3)2·6H2O (128 mg, 0.255 mmol), NEt4Cl (42 mg, 0.255 mmol) and demineralized water (2 mL) were placed in a 15 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure (ca. 1.1 MPa). Light yellow crystals of complex 1 appeared within two weeks.

elements.content: CB6·5H2O (35 mg, 0.032 mmol), an 8-fold excess of UO2(NO3)2·6H2O (128 mg, 0.255 mmol), dodecanedioic acid (30 mg, 0.130 mmol) and demineralized water (1.3 mL) were placed in a 10 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure (ca. 1.1 MPa). Light yellow crystals of complex 2, mixed with unreacted CB6, were obtained in low yield within five days. The same complex was obtained when dodecanedioic acid was replaced by a 2-fold excess of HCl.

elements.content: CB6·5H2O (17 mg, 0.016 mmol), a 16-fold excess of UO2(NO3)2·6H2O (128 mg, 0.255 mmol), formic acid (14 mg, 0.304 mmol) and demineralized water (1.8 mL) were placed in a 10 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure (ca. 1.1 MPa). Light yellow crystals of complex 3 appeared within 24 h (9 mg, 32% yield on the basis of CB6). Due to the presence of a small amount of insoluble, unreacted CB6 mixed with the crystals, the analysis corresponds to 3·0.5CB6. Anal. Calcd for C90H120N62O62U4: C, 26.93; H, 3.01; N, 21.63. Found: C, 27.06; H, 3.26; N, 21.51%. Crystals of 3, in low yield and mixed with unreacted CB6, were also obtained in the same conditions, but in the absence of formic acid (within six days), or in the presence of an additional 4-fold excess of NaNO3 or CsNO3.

elements.content: CB7·10H2O (12 mg, 0.009 mmol), a 10-fold excess of UO2(NO3)2·6H2O (43 mg, 0.086 mmol) and excess sulfuric acid (16 mg, 0.16 mmol, 96% solution in water) in demineralized water (1 mL) were placed in a 10 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure (ca. 1.1 MPa). Few light yellow crystals of complex 5 were obtained as extremely small and thin platelets within three weeks. Repeated attempts never gave more than a few crystals.

elements.content: CB6·5H2O (35 mg, 0.032 mmol), a 4-fold excess of UO2(NO3)2·6H2O (64 mg, 0.127 mmol) and excess sulfuric acid (20 mg, 0.20 mmol, 96% solution in water) in demineralized water (1.5 mL) were placed in a 10 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 160 °C under autogenous pressure (ca. 0.8 MPa). Few light yellow crystals of complex 6, likely involving CB8 present as an impurity in CB6 or resulting from partial transformation of CB6 under the conditions used, were obtained within three days, together with a white powder which was not further characterized. Repeated attempts never gave more than a few crystals.

elements.content: The data were collected at 100(2) K on a Nonius Kappa-CCD area detector diffractometer using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The crystals were introduced into glass capillaries with a protecting “Paratone-N” oil (Hampton Research) coating. The unit cell parameters were determined from ten frames, then refined on all data. The data (combinations of φ- and ω-scans giving complete data sets up to θ = 25.7° and a minimum redundancy of 4 for 90% of the reflections) were processed with HKL2000. The structures were solved by direct methods with SHELXS-97, expanded by subsequent Fourier-difference synthesis and refined by full-matrix (blocked matrix for compound 4) least-squares on F 2 with SHELXL-97. Absorption effects were corrected empirically with the program SCALEPACK. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. The carbon-bound hydrogen atoms were introduced at calculated positions. All hydrogen atoms were treated as riding atoms with an isotropic displacement parameter equal to 1.2 times that of the parent atom. Some voids in the lattice of all compounds likely indicate the presence of other, unresolved water molecules. Special details are as follows:
elements.clean_text:
Crystallography

The data were collected at 100(2) K on a Nonius Kappa-CCD area detector diffractometer using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The crystals were introduced into glass capillaries with a protecting "Paratone-N" oil (Hampton Research) coating. The unit cell parameters were determined from ten frames, then refined on all data. The data (combinations of φ- and ω-scans giving complete data sets up to θ = 25.7° and a minimum redundancy of 4 for 90% of the reflections) were processed with HKL2000. The structures were solved by direct methods with SHELXS-97, expanded by subsequent Fourier-difference synthesis and refined by full-matrix (blocked matrix for compound 4) least-squares on F 2 with SHELXL-97. Absorption effects were corrected empirically with the program SCALEPACK. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. The carbon-bound hydrogen atoms were introduced at calculated positions. All hydrogen atoms were treated as riding atoms with an isotropic displacement parameter equal to 1.2 times that of the parent atom. Some voids in the lattice of all compounds likely indicate the presence of other, unresolved water molecules. Special details are as follows:

elements.content: The five water molecules bound to the uranyl ion are disordered over two sites related by the inversion center and they have been refined with occupancy parameters of 0.5. Two water solvent molecules have also been given occupancy parameters of 0.5 in order to retain acceptable displacement parameters and also to account for a close contact between one of them and one of the disordered coordinated water molecules. Restraints on displacement parameters were applied for the atoms of the nitrate ion and one solvent molecule. The hydrogen atoms bound to oxygen atoms were not found, nor introduced.
elements.clean_text:
Compound 1 

The five water molecules bound to the uranyl ion are disordered over two sites related by the inversion center and they have been refined with occupancy parameters of 0.5. Two water solvent molecules have also been given occupancy parameters of 0.5 in order to retain acceptable displacement parameters and also to account for a close contact between one of them and one of the disordered coordinated water molecules. Restraints on displacement parameters were applied for the atoms of the nitrate ion and one solvent molecule. The hydrogen atoms bound to oxygen atoms were not found, nor introduced.

The sulfate ion is disordered over two positions sharing the sulfur and one oxygen atoms, both located on a binary axis. The hydrogen atoms bound to oxygen atoms were not found, nor introduced.

The hydrogen atoms bound to oxygen atoms were found on a Fourier-difference map, except for two solvent water molecules.

Crystal data and structure refinement parameters are given in Table and selected bond lengths and angles in Table . The molecular plots were drawn with SHELXTL and Balls & Sticks.

Results and Discussion

The reaction of uranyl nitrate and cucurbiturils was investigated under various experimental conditions, with common drawbacks being the formation of insoluble powders and/or the small quantity of crystals, which often prevented further characterization of the complexes; in fact, single crystals were only obtained in some out of numerous attempts. In all the successful syntheses described herein, a large excess of uranyl nitrate has been used (from 4- to 16-fold) and, apart from compound 1, all complexes have been obtained only under hydrothermal conditions. Acids such as HNO3, HCl or H2SO4 have been added in excess in several cases so as to promote cucurbituril dissolution. Organic acids have been used instead in other syntheses; in particular, carboxylic diacids with long aliphatic chains, such as sebacic and dodecanedioic acids, have been considered with the aim to form pseudorotaxane species (in fact, such a pseudorotaxane was obtained with the related azelaic acid, but it does not involve coordinated uranyl ions). These different added reactants, even when not present in the final products, result in the formation of compounds displaying a wide range of architectures.

Crystal data and structure refinement parameters are given in Table  and selected bond lengths and angles in Table . The molecular plots were drawn with SHELXTL  and Balls & Sticks. 

Results and Discussion

The reaction of uranyl nitrate and cucurbiturils was investigated under various experimental conditions, with common drawbacks being the formation of insoluble powders and/or the small quantity of crystals, which often prevented further characterization of the complexes; in fact, single crystals were only obtained in some out of numerous attempts. In all the successful syntheses described herein, a large excess of uranyl nitrate has been used (from 4- to 16-fold) and, apart from compound 1, all complexes have been obtained only under hydrothermal conditions. Acids such as HNO3, HCl or H2SO4 have been added in excess in several cases so as to promote cucurbituril dissolution. Organic acids have been used instead in other syntheses; in particular, carboxylic diacids with long aliphatic chains, such as sebacic and dodecanedioic acids, have been considered with the aim to form pseudorotaxane species (in fact, such a pseudorotaxane was obtained with the related azelaic acid, but it does not involve coordinated uranyl ions). These different added reactants, even when not present in the final products, result in the formation of compounds displaying a wide range of architectures.

Compounds [UO2(H2O)5](NO3)2·CB6·4H2O (1) and [UO2(NO3)2(H2O)2]·CB6·7H2O (2) were obtained at room temperature and/or under hydrothermal conditions, and they possess the same overall formula. In both of them, CB6 is a second-sphere ligand, hydrogen bonded to the uranyl complex moiety. The asymmetric unit in complex 1 corresponds to one uranyl ion located on an inversion center and half a CB6 molecule (Figure ). The uranyl ion is bound to five water molecules, which are disordered over two sets of positions in the equatorial plane (see ), with an average U−O bond length of 2.41(6) Å, in agreement with the value of 2.41(3) Å for the three other examples of uranyl penta(aqua) complexes reported in the CSD. Although the water hydrogen atoms were not found, due to the disorder present, some short O···O distances are indicative of the presence of hydrogen bonds involving the two adjacent carbonyl groups O7 and O9 as acceptors (Table ). Hydrogen bonded columns of alternate cations and CB6 molecules parallel to the c axis are thus formed. These columns are stacked along the b axis to give planar layers parallel to the bc plane and they are offset so that cations and CB6 molecules alternate also along the b axis. Such matching of “bumps” and “hollows” between adjacent columns is frequently observed in CB-based assemblages. The nitrate ions are located between these layers, with solvent water molecules bridging the different moieties. The shape of CB6 is quite regular, with O···O distances for diametrically opposite oxygen atoms in the range 6.75−6.93 Å.

The shape of CB6 is quite regular, with O⋅⋅⋅O distances for diametrically opposite oxygen atoms in the range 6.75-6.93 Å.

Compound 2 was obtained in the presence of an excess of either dodecanedioic acid or HCl, the former being used with the aim (not attained) of forming pseudorotaxane species. The asymmetric unit comprises one uranyl ion and two CB6 halves. The uranyl ion is bound to two nitrate ions in cis position and two water molecules; this cis geometry is exceptional since nearly all the [UO2(NO3)2(H2O)2] complexes in the CSD display trans geometries, the nitrate groups being adjacent only in two cases in which the water molecules are bridging two uranyl ions. In complex 2, this may be due to the two strong hydrogen bonds formed between the coordinated water molecules and two adjacent carbonyl oxygen atoms of one CB6 molecule. The average U−O(nitrate) and U−O(water) bond lengths of 2.528(18) and 2.38(5) Å are unexceptional [average values of 2.52(3) and 2.44(4) Å from the CSD]. Centrosymmetric, hydrogen bonded [UO2(NO3)2(H2O)2]2·CB6 sandwich groups are thus formed (Figure ), with eight solvent water molecules held around the two CB6 portals by hydrogen bonding. The second CB6 molecule is not hydrogen bonded to the uranyl species and it contains a centrosymmetric tetra-aqua motif. The water molecule O12 is hydrogen bonded as a donor to O11 and its image O11′ through the inversion center, whereas O11 is hydrogen bonded to two carbonyl oxygen atoms. The well-ordered (H2O)4 moiety is thus held in the CB6 cavity by four hydrogen bonds involving four carbonyl groups (Figure ). Water inclusion in CB6 molecules has previously been observed, as well as water-filled channels in columnar CB6 and CB8 species. The two independent CB6 molecules in 2, denoted A and B, are regular in shape (O···O distances for diametrically opposite oxygen atoms in the range 6.64−7.09 Å for A and 6.90−7.08 Å for B) and they are located at ca. 89° with respect to one another and in such manner that the sides of molecule B are facing the portals of the two proximal A molecules, with six CH···O interactions (or hydrogen bonds) formed on each side between some CH and CH2 protons of molecule B and carbonyl groups of A (Figure , H···O distances are in the range 2.30−2.60 Å). Such interactions have previously been observed in other CBs systems. Compound 2 is thus held by a large number of hydrogen bonds, either water−water, water−carbonyl or CH-carbonyl. However, apart from such interesting peculiar features, the two compounds 1 and 2 differ in no essential way from the uranyl/CB6 compound reported previously; in all these cases, the uranyl complex moiety interacts with CB6 through hydrogen bonds involving its aquo ligands, either directly or via solvent water molecules.
elements.clean_text: Compound 2 was obtained in the presence of an excess of either dodecanedioic acid or HCl, the former being used with the aim (not attained) of forming pseudorotaxane species. The asymmetric unit comprises one uranyl ion and two CB6 halves. The uranyl ion is bound to two nitrate ions in cis position and two water molecules; this cis geometry is exceptional since nearly all the [UO2(NO3)2(H2O)2] complexes in the CSD display trans geometries, the nitrate groups being adjacent only in two cases in which the water molecules are bridging two uranyl ions. In complex 2, this may be due to the two strong hydrogen bonds formed between the coordinated water molecules and two adjacent carbonyl oxygen atoms of one CB6 molecule. The average U-O(nitrate) and U-O(water) bond lengths of 2.528(18) and 2.38(5) Å are unexceptional [average values of 2.52(3) and 2.44(4) Å from the CSD]. Centrosymmetric, hydrogen bonded [UO2(NO3)2(H2O)2]2⋅CB6 sandwich groups are thus formed (Figure ), with eight solvent water molecules held around the two CB6 portals by hydrogen bonding. The second CB6 molecule is not hydrogen bonded to the uranyl species and it contains a centrosymmetric tetra-aqua motif. The water molecule O12 is hydrogen bonded as a donor to O11 and its image O11' through the inversion center, whereas O11 is hydrogen bonded to two carbonyl oxygen atoms. The well-ordered (H2O)4 moiety is thus held in the CB6 cavity by four hydrogen bonds involving four carbonyl groups (Figure ). Water inclusion in CB6 molecules has previously been observed, as well as water-filled channels in columnar CB6 and CB8 species. The two independent CB6 molecules in 2, denoted A and B, are regular in shape (O⋅⋅⋅O distances for diametrically opposite oxygen atoms in the range 6.64-7.09 Å for A and 6.90-7.08 Å for B) and they are located at ca. 89° with respect to one another and in such manner that the sides of molecule B are facing the portals of the two proximal A molecules, with six CH⋅⋅⋅O interactions (or hydrogen bonds) formed on each side between some CH and CH2 protons of molecule B and carbonyl groups of A (Figure , H⋅⋅⋅O distances are in the range 2.30-2.60 Å). Such interactions have previously been observed in other CBs systems. Compound 2 is thus held by a large number of hydrogen bonds, either water-water, water-carbonyl or CH-carbonyl. However, apart from such interesting peculiar features, the two compounds 1 and 2 differ in no essential way from the uranyl/CB6 compound reported previously; in all these cases, the uranyl complex moiety interacts with CB6 through hydrogen bonds involving its aquo ligands, either directly or via solvent water molecules.

Hydrogen bonds are shown as dashed lines. Carbon-bound hydrogen atoms are omitted. Bottom: Arrangement of the CB6 molecules with CH···O interactions shown as dashed lines. elements.content: Compound 3, [(UO2)4(CB6)O2(OH)2(H2O)6](NO3)2·CB6·8H2O, which was obtained under hydrothermal conditions either in the absence of acid or with an added excess of formic acid, and also in the presence of an excess of NaNO3 or CsNO3, brings forward some novel features. The asymmetric unit corresponds to two uranyl ions and two CB6 halves. The uranyl ions form a centrosymmetric, μ3-oxo bridged tetranuclear unit of quite frequent geometry, and similar (although with different lateral ligands) to that in the uranyl/CB6 species previously reported. However, atom U1 is also bound to a CB6 carbonyl group, with an U1−O10 bond length of 2.545(6) Å (Figure ). Together with the other structures reported hereafter, this is the first instance of uranium bonding to a CB molecule, so that the U−O distance can only be compared to those in the uranyl complexes of urea derivatives reported in the CSD, which average to 2.36(4) Å. The much larger distance in 3 may be due in part to the bulkiness of the tetranuclear uranyl moiety (see below). The uranium atoms are also bound to either one (U1) or two (U2) μ3-oxo (O5), one μ2-hydroxo (O6) and one μ2-aquo (O8) ligands, with unexceptional average bond lengths of 2.22(7), 2.45(2) and 2.67(13) Å, the bonds with O8 being however very asymmetric. The pentagonal bipyramidal coordination environment of both atoms is completed by a terminal water molecule (O7 and O9), with an average bond length of 2.44(4) Å. The coordination polyhedra thus share two (U1) or three (U2) sides with their neighbors, the tetranuclear assembly being nearly planar [the dihedral angle between the mean equatorial planes of U1 and U2 is 13.6(2)°]. The CB6 molecule coordinated to uranyl is located in such manner that it is involved in hydrogen bonds with both the bridging and terminal aquo ligands [one direct and one mediated by a water molecule (O25) for O8 and two direct for O9], so that CB6 is both a first- and a second-sphere ligand for uranyl. This arrangement results in the formation of chains of alternate uranyl assemblies and CB6 molecules directed along the [1 1 0] direction, with a dihedral angle of 99.8° between the U4 and the average CB6 planes. The second, uncoordinated CB6 molecule is at right angle with the first one (dihedral angle 90.8°) and, as in compound 2, numerous CH···O interactions are present, with H···O distances in the range 2.14−2.57 Å. This second CB6 molecule is also hydrogen bonded to the terminal aquo ligand (O7), which points on the side of the chain. The distances between diametrically opposite oxygen atoms are in the ranges 6.62−7.14 and 6.65−7.16 Å in the two CB6 molecules, respectively. The uranyl-bonded chains are tightly packed alongside one another in the ab plane, with an offset so that the “bumps” (CB6 molecules) of one match the “hollows” (uranyl assemblies) of the other. The layers thus formed are separated along the c axis by layers of uncoordinated CB6 molecules, thus giving a three-dimensional framework held by weak interactions. The counterions and water solvent molecules are located in the intermolecular spaces, where they are held by hydrogen bonding.

elements.content: The complex [(UO2)2(CB6)3(H2O)6][(UO2)2(NO3)4(C10H16O4)]2·CB6·8H2O (4) was obtained under hydrothermal conditions in the presence of sebacic acid which, as dodecanedioic acid in the case of complex 2, was intended to possibly form a pseudorotaxane species. By contrast with compound 2, 4 displays uranyl coordination by CB6 and also the presence of a dianionic uranyl sebacate complex. The asymmetric unit comprises three uranyl ions, one (U1) bound to two CB6 molecules (one of them on an inversion center) and the other two (U2 and U3) to the sebacate ligand. Atom U1 is bound to two carbonyl atoms from two CB6 molecules, which are adjacent in its equatorial plane, with an average bond length of 2.38(4) Å in agreement with the average value of 2.36(4) Å for urea derivatives reported in the CSD, which suggests that the larger distance in 3 could be due to steric effects. The uranium coordination sphere is completed by three water molecules [average bond length 2.388(15) Å], thus giving the usual pentagonal bipyramidal geometry. The centrosymmetric, tetracationic dinuclear complex thus formed (Figure ) is a triple-decker sandwich complex analogous to the previously reported gadolinium complex [Gd2(CB6)3(H2O)8]. The latter is a cylinder with an approximate largest length of ca. 30 Å, whereas the length in 4 is about 26 Å only, indicating a more compact assemblage. The central CB6 is much tilted with respect to the lateral one (dihedral angle ca. 75°), and both are nearly perpendicular to the uranyl equatorial plane (dihedral angles of ca. 80°). This arrangement is associated with the presence of 12 CH···O interactions between some CH and CH2 groups of the central CB6 and the carbonyl groups of the lateral ones (H···O distances in the range 2.16−2.48 Å). The three CB6 molecules in the complex are thus held together by both coordination bonds and weak interactions. One of the aquo ligands (O9) is also hydrogen bonded to the carbonyl atom O24 of the central CB6. As in complex 3, the CB6 molecules are thus both first- and second-sphere ligands. These dinuclear complexes are stacked alongside one another along the a axis, with a tilt bringing the lateral CB6 of one complex in a suitable position to form CH···O interactions with the central CB6 of the neighboring complex (H···O distances in the range 2.33−2.66 Å). These rows parallel to a are stacked so as to form sheets parallel to (0 1 1̅), in which the spaces between the complex moieties, also arranged in rows parallel to a, are occupied by the uncoordinated CB6 molecules. The latter are both involved in four hydrogen bonds with the aquo ligands of the neighboring uranyl complexes and in CH···O interactions with the four proximal CB6 molecules: the lateral ligands of two complexes act as donors (H···O distances in the range 2.44−2.54 Å) and those of two other complexes as acceptors (2.34−2.68 Å). This results in the formation of a tightly packed two-dimensional framework held by both coordination bonds and weak interactions (Figure ). If the uranyl ions are neglected, the layers appear to comprise a herringbone arrangement of CB6 molecules with their main axis rotated by about 75 and 86° between first neighbors along the two directions (the uncoordinated CB6 and the central coordinated one being equivalent in this respect, and nearly parallel with an angle of 13.8° between their main axis). Each molecule is a donor in CH···O hydrogen bonds on its two sides and an acceptor through its two portals and it thus interacts with four neighboring molecules. A planar arrangement of CB6 complexes was also observed in the previously reported three-decker Gd(III) species, but in this case no uncoordinated CB6 is present and the complex moieties are oriented at ca. 90° with respect to one another, whereas herringbone arrangements of CB molecules similar to that observed in 4 have previously been observed. Curiously, the uncoordinated CB6 molecule in 4 is more distorted than the coordinated ones, with distances between diametrically opposite oxygen atoms in the range 6.46−7.45 Å in the former and 6.84−7.11 Å in the latter two. The counteranion [(UO2)2(NO3)4(C10H16O4)] is a complex of uranyl nitrate with the sebacate ligand (Figure ). Uranyl sebacate has previously been investigated and it has been shown to give uranyl-organic frameworks (UOFs) under hydrothermal conditions. In [(UO2)(C10H16O4)], dinuclear uranyl subunits are linked by the sebacate ligands (with bridging bi- and tridentate coordination modes) to give a two-dimensional framework, whereas in [(UO2)2(C10H16O4)2(C10H8N2)], a mixed-ligand two-dimensional framework is formed, with both bidentate and bridging bidentate coordination modes of the sebacate ligand. In complex 4, each sebacate molecule is chelating one uranyl ion at both ends, with an unexceptional average U−O bond length of 2.442(13) Å [average value of 2.48(4) Å from the CSD for chelating carboxylates and eight-coordination of uranium]. Two nitrate groups complete the uranyl coordination sphere [average U−O bond length 2.48(4) Å] to give the hexagonal bipyramidal uranium environment usual for small-bite chelating ligands. The central part of the sebacate aliphatic chain is extended along the c axis, but the two extremities are kinked so that the complex assumes a sinuous shape. The dianions are located between the layers, with the central part of sebacate spanning the interlayer space obliquely (Figure ).

elements.content: Due to their later discovery and lesser availability, CB7 and CB8 have been the subject of far less studies than CB6. This is particularly evident from the crystallographic point of view since, whereas the CSD contains 146 structures involving CB6, there are 32 with CB8 and only 6 with CB7. To the best of our knowledge, no example of metal-complexed CB7 has been reported, although encapsulation of small metal complexes has been demonstrated. Attempts to grow crystals of the uranyl complex of CB7 in conditions analogous to those used for CB6 have failed up to now, but tiny single crystals of the complex [(UO2)2(CB7)(SO4)2(H2O)2]·4H2O (5) could be obtained under hydrothermal conditions in the presence of H2SO4. The asymmetric unit in 5 comprises half a uranyl sulfate moiety and a quarter of CB7, the latter molecule admitting two symmetry planes, one parallel to the equatorial plane of the macrocycle and containing all the HC-CH groups and the other containing the main macrocycle axis, two methylene bridges (C15 and its image through the first plane) and crossing the opposite glycoluril unit through the two carbonyl atoms (O8 and its image through the first plane). The uranyl ion is bound to the carbonyl atom O9 of two CB7 molecules, with an U−O9 bond length of 2.433(7) Å slightly larger than that in compound 4 and two oxygen atoms from two sulfate ions (the sulfate ions are disordered around a binary axis, see ), with an average U−O bond length of 2.312(16) Å (taking both disordered positions into account), in agreement with the average value of 2.37(4) Å for nonchelating sulfates in the CSD. One water molecule (O7), located on the symmetry plane containing the uranyl ion, completes the coordination sphere to give a pentagonal bipyramidal uranium environment (Figure ). Each sulfate ion is bound in monodentate fashion to two uranyl ions, which results in the formation of dinuclear dimeric [(UO2)2(SO4)2] subunits with the S···S line parallel to the a axis. Each of these neutral subunits is bound to four CB7 molecules to give a two-dimensional framework extending parallel to the ac plane, which is made of alternating rows of uranyl and CB7 moieties. The U···U distance along a is equal to the unit cell parameter, 10.6909(7) Å, whereas the separation between CB7 molecules along this axis is ca. 1.6 Å (when taking van der Waals radii into account). When viewed along the c axis, the CB7 molecules in one sheet are alternately on one side and the other of the mean plane, which gives the sheets a strongly corrugated shape. The convex parts of one sheet correspond to the grooves of its neighbors along the b axis, but the offset of 1/2 along the a axis brings the CB7 of one sheet in correspondence with the uranyl sulfate groups of its neighbors, thus preventing close contacts between the CB7 molecules. The most interesting feature of this structure is the formation of extended channels along the a axis resulting from the packing of CB7 molecules. The diameter of CB7 at the portal level is about 5.4 Å (after correction for the oxygen van der Waals radius), but the effective diameter of the channels is reduced by the uranyl aquo ligands pointing toward the cavity center, and, in projection down the a axis, the smallest dimensions of the available space can be estimated at ca. 5 × 3 Å. The size of the channels is however quite irregular, with largest dimensions corresponding to the inner cavity size of CB7, ca. 7.3 Å in diameter, and they are occupied by hydrogen bonded water molecules (the voids present in the lattice indicate that the number of free water molecules is probably larger than found). The small gap between CB7 molecules along the a axis ensures a nearly continuous channel wall. This porous, columnar architecture can be viewed as an assemblage of nanotubules, analogous to those reported for metal-free CB6 and CB8, in which the separation of CB molecules along the channel amounts to 1.3 and 1.9 Å, and is thus very close to the value in 5. Nanotubular channels have also been found in metal-complexed CBs, but the continuity of the would-be channel is often interrupted by the metal atoms located between the CB molecules. The interest of uranyl complexation in 5 is that it brings about a close, parallel packing of the CB7 molecules, while the metal ions remain at the periphery of the CB portals. The shape of the CB7 molecule in 5 seems little modified by uranyl complexation, with O···O distances and O···O···O angles between successive carbonyl oxygen atoms in a portal spanning the ranges 3.48−4.09 Å and 121−132°, respectively. These values for the CB7 structures reported in the CSD span larger ranges, 3.24−4.02 Å and 103−147° (excluding the inverted CB7), but, if only the macrocycles containing small organic molecules as guests are considered, the ranges are reduced to 3.35−3.86 Å and 119−139°.

This porous, columnar architecture can be viewed as an assemblage of nanotubules, analogous to those reported for metal-free CB6 and CB8, in which the separation of CB molecules along the channel amounts to 1.3 and 1.9 Å, and is thus very close to the value in 5. Nanotubular channels have also been found in metal-complexed CBs, but the continuity of the would-be channel is often interrupted by the metal atoms located between the CB molecules. The interest of uranyl complexation in 5 is that it brings about a close, parallel packing of the CB7 molecules, while the metal ions remain at the periphery of the CB portals. The shape of the CB7 molecule in 5 seems little modified by uranyl complexation, with O⋅⋅⋅O distances and O⋅⋅⋅O⋅⋅⋅O angles between successive carbonyl oxygen atoms in a portal spanning the ranges 3.48-4.09 Å and 121-132°, respectively. These values for the CB7 structures reported in the CSD span larger ranges, 3.24-4.02 Å and 103-147° (excluding the inverted CB7), but, if only the macrocycles containing small organic molecules as guests are considered, the ranges are reduced to 3.35-3.86 Å and 119-139°.

elements.content: When CB6 is reacted with uranyl nitrate in the presence of sulfuric acid, in conditions analogous to those leading to complex 5, the only crystals obtained, in very small quantity but in a reproducible manner, do not contain CB6, but CB8, seemingly present as an impurity in commercial CB6 or resulting from partial transformation of CB6 under the conditions used. The structure of [(UO2)6(CB8)(SO4)6(H2O)10]·18H2O (6) is all the more interesting that this compound, after the Bi(III) and Sr(II) complexes, is only the third example of metal-coordinated CB8. The asymmetric unit contains three uranyl and three sulfate ions, and half a centrosymmetric CB8 molecule (Figure ). Atoms U1 and U2 are both bound to one carbonyl oxygen atom, with an average U−O bond length of 2.369(12) Å in agreement with those in complexes 4 and 5. Each CB8 molecule is thus bound to four uranium atoms, through two centrosymmetrically related groups of two adjacent glycoluril units, these units being coordinated on one and the other side. CB8 is thus doubly monodentate at each portal, with the two oxygen donors far apart from one another, whereas it is chelating, bidentate and doubly bidentate at each portal, respectively, in the Bi(III) and Sr(II) complexes. The shape of CB8 in 6 is distinctly elongated, with largest and smallest distances of 13.588 and 11.803 Å between methylene carbon atoms opposite to one another in one portal, the coordinated glycoluril groups being farther apart from one another than the uncoordinated ones, with distances between diametrically opposite oxygen atoms of 10.23 and 10.74 Å in the former case and 9.26 and 9.49 Å in the latter. CB8 is also involved in two hydrogen bonds, with the aquo ligand O19 and its image by symmetry. The three sulfate ions are bridging, with two of them (S1 and S2) connecting three uranium atoms [U1, U2 and U3 for S2, U1, U2 and the image of U3 through the screw axis in (0 y 1/4) for S1] and the third (S3) bridging U1 and U3. The average U−O(sulfate) bond length, 2.36(3) Å, is in perfect agreement with the average value of 2.37(4) Å from the CSD. The uranyl coordination spheres are completed by one (U1) or two (U2 and U3) water molecules [average U−O bond length 2.44(5) Å] to give pentagonal bipyramidal uranium environments with dihedral angles of 17.8(2), 39.7(2) and 25.7(2)° between the mean equatorial planes associated to the couples (U1, U2), (U2, U3) and (U1, U3), respectively. The uranyl sulfate polymeric subunit is an undulated ribbon running along the b axis. Uranyl sulfate ribbons (or double chains) involving only triply bridging sulfate ions are encountered in the [UO2SO4(H2O)2] motif, in which each uranium atom is bound to three sulfate oxygen atoms, whereas U2 in 6 is bound to only two. Anionic ribbons including triply bridging sulfate ions are also present in organically templated uranyl sulfates. However, an arrangement identical to that observed in 6 does not seem to have been described previously. The three uranyl groups and the three sulfate ions in the asymmetric unit build a motif identical to that in the [UO2SO4(H2O)2] polymer, but the regular arrangement is disrupted by the absence of a third coordinated metal on the sulfate containing S3. The ribbon can thus be seen as an assemblage of such motifs, tilted with respect to one another, through isolated U3−O10 bridges. Each of these trinuclear motifs is bound to two CB8 molecules and, conversely, each portal of CB8 is bound to two such motifs, which results in the formation of a two-dimensional framework parallel to the (1 0 2̅) plane. The planar sheets are built from alternate uranyl sulfate chains and rows of CB8 molecules, the latter being roughly perpendicular to the sheet plane and the successive rows, related by a binary screw axis, being offset by half the b cell parameter. These layers are very tightly packed with, as previously observed, a correspondence between the “bumps” (CB8) of one sheet and the “hollows” (uranyl sulfate chains) of its neighbors. Cylindrical channels appear when the packing of CB8 molecules alone is viewed down the [1 0 1] axis (not in the layer plane), but these channels are interrupted by the uranyl sulfate chains. Nine solvent water molecules are present for each trinuclear subunit and an intricate network of hydrogen bonds connecting complexed and free water molecules and sulfate and carbonyl oxygen atoms (both intra- and interlayer) is formed.

elements.content: The results reported herein evidence some novel features concerning the interaction between cucurbiturils and f element ions. Whereas complexation with these molecules was up to now limited to lanthanide ions, four of the complexes reported (3−6) show that, besides second-sphere complexation through hydrogen bonding, direct uranyl−carbonyl bonds can be formed, with bond lengths generally identical to those found in the case of urea derivatives. The nitrate ions are dissociated in these compounds and some uranyl ions are bound to two carbonyl groups from two different molecules, thus opening the way to polynuclear complexes, as in 4 and 5. However, bidentate chelation of uranyl by CBs is observed in no case, while this is a frequent occurrence with more spherical metal ions, such as alkali, alkaline-earth and lanthanide ions, indicating that the geometry of proximal oxygen atoms in CBs is likely maladapted to meet the peculiar requirements of the uranyl ion. In the cases in which uranyl coordination occurs, the presence of second-sphere hydrogen bonding interactions between aquo ligands and uncomplexed carbonyl oxygen atoms is present in most cases (3, 4 and 6) and it likely adds to the stability of the complexes formed. In the second-sphere complex 2, as well as in the one-dimensional polymeric complex 3 and the dinuclear complex 4, CH···O interactions between CB6 molecules are present, and are even of intramolecular nature in the dinuclear complex unit. In compounds 5 and 6, obtained in the presence of excess sulfuric acid, sulfate replaces nitrate in the uranyl coordination sphere, which results in the formation of dimeric (5) or one-dimensional polymeric (6) uranyl sulfate neutral subunits. Coordination to tetradentate CBs extends the structure toward higher dimensionality, with formation of layers and, in the case of complex 5, cylindrical channels resulting from a regular stacking of parallel CB7 molecules. In both cases, it is to be noted that the CB molecules are fully integrated in the fabric of the uranyl-organic framework, and are not simply present as guests or templating species. These complexes thus represent a novel family in the rapidly evolving field of uranyl-organic architectures.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

The results reported herein evidence some novel features concerning the interaction between cucurbiturils and f element ions. Whereas complexation with these molecules was up to now limited to lanthanide ions, four of the complexes reported (3-6) show that, besides second-sphere complexation through hydrogen bonding, direct uranyl-carbonyl bonds can be formed, with bond lengths generally identical to those found in the case of urea derivatives. The nitrate ions are dissociated in these compounds and some uranyl ions are bound to two carbonyl groups from two different molecules, thus opening the way to polynuclear complexes, as in 4 and 5. However, bidentate chelation of uranyl by CBs is observed in no case, while this is a frequent occurrence with more spherical metal ions, such as alkali, alkaline-earth and lanthanide ions, indicating that the geometry of proximal oxygen atoms in CBs is likely maladapted to meet the peculiar requirements of the uranyl ion. In the cases in which uranyl coordination occurs, the presence of second-sphere hydrogen bonding interactions between aquo ligands and uncomplexed carbonyl oxygen atoms is present in most cases (3, 4 and 6) and it likely adds to the stability of the complexes formed. In the second-sphere complex 2, as well as in the one-dimensional polymeric complex 3 and the dinuclear complex 4, CH⋅⋅⋅O interactions between CB6 molecules are present, and are even of intramolecular nature in the dinuclear complex unit. In compounds 5 and 6, obtained in the presence of excess sulfuric acid, sulfate replaces nitrate in the uranyl coordination sphere, which results in the formation of dimeric (5) or one-dimensional polymeric (6) uranyl sulfate neutral subunits. Coordination to tetradentate CBs extends the structure toward higher dimensionality, with formation of layers and, in the case of complex 5, cylindrical channels resulting from a regular stacking of parallel CB7 molecules. In both cases, it is to be noted that the CB molecules are fully integrated in the fabric of the uranyl-organic framework, and are not simply present as guests or templating species. These complexes thus represent a novel family in the rapidly evolving field of uranyl-organic architectures.

CB6·5H2O (35 mg, 0.032 mmol) and a 4-fold excess of UO2(NO3)2·6H2O (64 mg, 0.127 mmol) were dissolved in demineralized water (3 mL) and 0.5 mL of HNO3 (65% in water) was added. Upon standing at room temperature, the solution deposited light yellow crystals of complex 1 within one day. The product was recovered after filtration and washed with water (17 mg, 34% yield on the basis of CB6). Anal. Calcd for C36H54N26O29U: C, 27.84; H, 3.51; N, 23.45. Found: C, 27.52; H, 3.60; N, 23.18%. The same complex was also obtained under hydrothermal conditions: CB6·5H2O (35 mg, 0.032 mmol), an 8-fold excess of UO2(NO3)2·6H2O (128 mg, 0.255 mmol), NEt4Cl (42 mg, 0.255 mmol) and demineralized water (2 mL) were placed in a 15 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure (ca. 1.1 MPa). Light yellow crystals of complex 1 appeared within two weeks.

[UO<sub>2</sub>(NO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>]·CB6·7H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>2</bold>)

CB6·5H2O (35 mg, 0.032 mmol), an 8-fold excess of UO2(NO3)2·6H2O (128 mg, 0.255 mmol), dodecanedioic acid (30 mg, 0.130 mmol) and demineralized water (1.3 mL) were placed in a 10 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure (ca. 1.1 MPa). Light yellow crystals of complex 2, mixed with unreacted CB6, were obtained in low yield within five days. The same complex was obtained when dodecanedioic acid was replaced by a 2-fold excess of HCl.

[(UO<sub>2</sub>)<sub>4</sub>(CB6)O<sub>2</sub>(OH)<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>6</sub>](NO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>·CB6·8H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>3</bold>)

CB6·5H2O (17 mg, 0.016 mmol), a 16-fold excess of UO2(NO3)2·6H2O (128 mg, 0.255 mmol), formic acid (14 mg, 0.304 mmol) and demineralized water (1.8 mL) were placed in a 10 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure (ca. 1.1 MPa). Light yellow crystals of complex 3 appeared within 24 h (9 mg, 32% yield on the basis of CB6). Due to the presence of a small amount of insoluble, unreacted CB6 mixed with the crystals, the analysis corresponds to 3·0.5CB6. Anal. Calcd for C90H120N62O62U4: C, 26.93; H, 3.01; N, 21.63. Found: C, 27.06; H, 3.26; N, 21.51%. Crystals of 3, in low yield and mixed with unreacted CB6, were also obtained in the same conditions, but in the absence of formic acid (within six days), or in the presence of an additional 4-fold excess of NaNO3 or CsNO3.

[(UO<sub>2</sub>)<sub>2</sub>(CB6)<sub>3</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>6</sub>][(UO<sub>2</sub>)<sub>2</sub>(NO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>4</sub>(C<sub>10</sub>H<sub>16</sub>O<sub>4</sub>)]<sub>2</sub>·CB6·8H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>4</bold>)

CB6·5H2O (35 mg, 0.032 mmol), an 8-fold excess of UO2(NO3)2·6H2O (128 mg, 0.255 mmol), sebacic acid (26 mg, 0.128 mmol) and demineralized water (1.7 mL) were placed in a 10 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure (ca. 1.1 MPa). Light yellow crystals of complex 4 were obtained in very low yield within three days. Repeated attempts never gave more than a few crystals.

[(UO<sub>2</sub>)<sub>2</sub>(CB7)(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>]·4H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>5</bold>)

CB7·10H2O (12 mg, 0.009 mmol), a 10-fold excess of UO2(NO3)2·6H2O (43 mg, 0.086 mmol) and excess sulfuric acid (16 mg, 0.16 mmol, 96% solution in water) in demineralized water (1 mL) were placed in a 10 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure (ca. 1.1 MPa). Few light yellow crystals of complex 5 were obtained as extremely small and thin platelets within three weeks. Repeated attempts never gave more than a few crystals.

[(UO<sub>2</sub>)<sub>6</sub>(CB8)(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>6</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>10</sub>]·18H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>6</bold>)

CB6·5H2O (35 mg, 0.032 mmol), a 4-fold excess of UO2(NO3)2·6H2O (64 mg, 0.127 mmol) and excess sulfuric acid (20 mg, 0.20 mmol, 96% solution in water) in demineralized water (1.5 mL) were placed in a 10 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 160 °C under autogenous pressure (ca. 0.8 MPa). Few light yellow crystals of complex 6, likely involving CB8 present as an impurity in CB6 or resulting from partial transformation of CB6 under the conditions used, were obtained within three days, together with a white powder which was not further characterized. Repeated attempts never gave more than a few crystals.
